                                                    Politico
Your guide to the permanent campaign 

            By 
Elena Schneider

09/14/15, 10:03 AM EDT
The following newsletter is an abridged version of Campaign Pro's Morning Score. For an earlier morning read on exponentially more races — and for a more comprehensive aggregation of the day's most important campaign news — sign up for Campaign Pro today. (http://www.politicopro.com/proinfo)
TAR HEEL STATE PARTY TROUBLES -- The North Carolina Republican Party has a lot on the line in 2016 - a battleground state in a presidential yea, one of the tightest governor's races in the country, and an incumbent senator to protect. But GOP leaders and the state party Chairman Hasan Harnett are struggling with trust issues, or as one Republican familiar with these discussions put it: "[Harnett] will tell you one thing, and then two days later, he'll do a complete 180 on it." This summer, the party lost its executive director, and within weeks, lost its interim executive director, too. Without one, there is more chatter that the Republican National Committee might run its money through a county party, instead of the state, like former Sen. Kay Hagan did in 2014 when the state's Democratic Party was in turmoil. 
"I'm almost sure that's going to happen," another local GOP strategist said. "Now, they're trying to work around [Harnett], and isolate him." But Paul Shumaker, Senator Richard Burr's (R-N.C.) campaign consultant, said there is "no decision" yet to change the funding structure. "Without knowing who the executive director is, everybody's going to leave a lot of options on the table," he said. However, Niger Innis, a Republican activist, said that while the Harnett has been willing to work with the "old guard" in the state, the establishment hasn't reciprocated. "Is the Republican Party ready for the repercussions of attempting to force failure upon the first black chairman of North Carolina?" Innis said. 
North Carolina isn't alone in its troubles. Colorado's state GOP may have papered over its in-fighting for now, but they struggled with accusations of extortion involving the state attorney general. In Nevada, the Las Vegas Journal-Review editorial board earlier this month called on the GOP chairman, Michael McDonald, to resign, following allegations fraud, calling him, "disgraceful." http://bit.ly/1Y1Ty9M 
FIRST IN SCORE -- AIR WAR, ON JUDGES -- The Judicial Crisis Network, a conservative group, reserved $200,000 worth of airtime and digital ad space in Iowa, New Hampshire and Washington, D.C., challenging Republican candidates ahead of Wednesday's debate to declare their positions on Supreme Court appointments. "We can't afford more surprises," the ad says, over images of Chief Justice John Roberts, Justice Anthony Kennedy, and retired Justice David Souter, all appointed by Republican presidents, who've all taken positions that didn't please some conservatives. Watch here: http://bit.ly/1NyJ5iF
Days until the 2015 election: 50. Days until the 2016 election: 421.
Thanks for joining us. Email tips to the whole Campaign Pro team at sshepard@politico.com, kcheney@politico.com, eschneider@politico.com, krobillard@politico.com and tmeyer@politico.com. 
AIR WAR, ON IMMIGRATION -- A six-figure ad buy this week will attack Donald Trump, Texas Sen. Ted Cruz and Wisconsin Gov. Scott Walker for their comments on immigration, juxtaposing them with another Republican - Ronald Reagan. The National Immigration Forum Forum Action Fund reserved six-figures worth of airtime on CNN, MSNBC and Fox News during pre- and post-debate coverage. The Washington Post first reported the ad buy. http://wapo.st/1OP1i8Z 
TAKING IT ALL -- "The Key to Winning Down Ballot Races," by Larry J. Sabato, Kyle Kondik and Geoffrey Skelley in POLITICO's Magazine: "Down-ballot races are increasingly decided by who wins the White House. To grasp this fact, it's best to focus on two numbers: 6 percent and .781 ... 1. To win the Senate, win the White House ... 2. The year's most important Senate primary (Florida) ... 3. Will any incumbents face primary trouble? (Not really.) ... 4. More retirements are coming." http://politi.co/1VWW4fq 
YOUTH VOTE -- Sen. Rob Portman's campaign said it's mobilizing young voters with its Students for Portman coalition, and it's going after them on Instagram, too. Portman's staff said in a press release that it's the first Senate campaign to use the picture filter platform, micro-targeting Ohio State University students this weekend during the first football home game. 
** A message from Pandora: Pandora reaches over 70 million monthly voting-age listeners who listen on average over 2 hours per day. Pandora offers scale and precision political targeting solutions to reach your target voter anytime, anywhere.**
2016 IN TWO MINUTES - PRESIDENTIAL REPLAY -- CARLY for America out with a new web video backing former Hewlett-Packard executive, where she pushes back on Donald Trump's criticism of her looks in a Rolling Stone article, while also emphasizing female leadership in the Republican Party. "Ladies, look at this face ... This is the face of a 61-year-old woman. I am proud of every year and every wrinkle." Watch here: http://bit.ly/1Y1EGrY 
-- Fiorina hit those lines on a campaign stop in Scottsdale, Ariz., POLITICO's Hadas Gold reported. http://politi.co/1ETFSHE 
-- The San Francisco Chronicle does a deep dive into Fiorina's 2010 Senate campaign, which they call a roadmap for her opponents to use against her as the campaign heats up. http://bit.ly/1M5OpXx 
SUBTLE SIGNS -- "Marco Rubio's Mormon play," Campaign Pro's Elena Schneider: "Rubio is subtly leveraging his LDS background to build support in Nevada, where the state's LDS community isn't huge - Mormons make up just a small percentage of the population - but represents an influential constituency in Republican politics. Rubio has held kitchen table meetings and private meet-and-greets with prominent LDS Church leaders, lining up support from some of the top Mormon names in Nevada politics, including Lt. Gov. Mark Hutchison. Hutchison recently barnstormed northern Nevada with Rubio, personally introducing the Florida senator at stops along the way." http://politi.co/1NyWSFU
NOT-SO-SUBTLE SIGNS -- "Trump vs. Walker: A tale of two tailgates," by POLITICO's Katie Glueck in Ames, Iowa: "The stage, the heat and the drunk college kids they faced were the same. But the receptions Scott Walker and Donald Trump received when they stumped at the same Iowa event Saturday couldn't have been more different - or revealing. The tailgate party scene at the annual Iowa State-University of Iowa football game was tailor-made for the Wisconsin governor, a football fan who's at his retail politicking-best when playing the Midwestern everyman role. ...But Walker was nearly inaudible in his remarks, the fault of too-weak speakers in the tailgate tent. It didn't matter much anyway: it quickly became apparent that many of the hundreds of attendees who had packed into and around the tent, sponsored by the Iowa GOP, couldn't see the main stage, and thought - and hoped - they were watching Trump instead." http://politi.co/1Nr5uwH 
CODA - QUOTE OF THE DAY: "They made it very boring and plain." -- Rep.-elect Darin LaHood (R-Ill.), on moving this week into former Rep. Aaron Schock's offices -- which were notoriously decorated like a scene from "Downton Abbey" but have since been painted over. http://bit.ly/1VXen48
** A message from Pandora: Music streaming is on pace to double in 2015* as millions of listeners tune in every day. Pandora offers precision targeting solutions to target voters by age, gender, location, political affiliation and more with premium audio, video and display advertising solutions across all devices and platforms.
Pandora’s monthly voting-age listeners by state: New Hampshire: 287,830; Iowa: 576,965; Nevada: 667,646; South Carolina: 961,417; Ohio: 2,321,265; Florida: 4,655,984
To learn more about how we can help you win contact Sean Duggan, VP Advertising, (917) 403-0259 or sduggan@pandora.com **

                                             and 
                                                    Lindsey M. Burke

Walter Laqueur

                                            By 
                                                    Larry J. Sabato
                                            ,
                                                    Kyle Kondik
                                             and 
                                                    Geoffrey Skelley

Elena Schneider is a campaign pro reporter for POLITICO, where she focuses on House races and North Carolina. Before joining the 2016 politics team, Schneider was a news assistant and freelancer for the New York Times’ DC bureau. Her work has also appeared in the Texas Tribune, Texas Monthly and Business Insider.
She earned a Master’s and a Bachelor’s in Journalism from Northwestern University’s Medill School of Journalism. Schneider is a North Carolina native and an even-in-September Chicago Cubs fan.
